subject: Re: [junit] Re: Recursive TestRunner -- one implementation
msgSnippet: Hi Jeff. Interesting post! ... If you can t call a class directly (due to incompatibility arising from different class loaders) then you can t call a class
messageBody:
Hi Jeff. Interesting post!

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 02:11, Jeff Grigg wrote:

> *BUT* for any of this to work, the classes under test must be loaded
> with a custom class loader. This is the rub: Standard JUnit test
> runners load the TestCase classes using the standard Java class
> loader. So when I load the application classes using the
> jAdvise/javassist class loader, the tests can only communicate with
> the application objects using Reflection, because classes and
> interfaces are incompatible when loaded with different class
> loaders. Writing all test logic using Reflection would be really
> unpleasant. So I need to load the TestCase classes with the
> jAdvise/javassist class loader.

If you can't call a class directly (due to incompatibility arising from
different class loaders) then you can't call a class indirectly (using
reflection). Reflection allows you to call methods dynamically, but not
to circumvent type checking. You can try, but I think you'll find it
impossible. (Of course, trying it yourself with tests is much better
than believing what you read on mailing lists!)

>
> Hmmm...
>
> Here's what I do:
> Each test method that needs to run under jAdvise/javassist checks to
> see if it was loaded by a JUnit runner or jAdvise. If it was loaded
> by a JUnit runner, it calls a common method that fires up jAdvise,
> loads the class with the custom class loader, and then calls the
> same method in the loaded class. (It also calls setUp & tearDown in
> the other class.)
>
> Here's what it looks like:
> | public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
> | final boolean runningInCustomClassLoader;
> | public MyTestCase() { super("MyTestCase");
> | this.runningInCustomClassLoader = true; }
> | public MyTestCase(String name) { super(name);
> | this.runningInCustomClassLoader = false; }
> |
> | public void testMethod() {
> | if (this.runningInCustomClassLoader) {
> | // Do application testing here.
> | } else { // called by JUnit
> | callSelfInCustomClassLoader();
> | } } }
>
> Crazy, eh? ;->

Yes, a little ;)

>
> (In Java 1.4 there's an easy way to get a useful stack trace --
> so 'callSelfInCustomClassLoader' can determine the caller's class
> and method name.)
>
